The Act strengthens criminal penalties for methamphetamine trafficking and establishes new controls over precursor chemicals.
column5: No, the legislation would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The legislation is a public record and not an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter. Therefore, it is not protected under FOIA exemption 5. There is no case law needed to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the exemption.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Law Enforcement:    The Administration has significantly stepped up its efforts in methamphetamine law enforcement, particularly with respect to the Organized Crime and Drug Enforcement Task Force ["OCDETF"] efforts and the establishment of a Midwest High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area ["HIDTA"].  As of September 1996, all U.S. Attorneys have provided district plans assessing the current threat and ways to address it, and establishing coordination groups among community agencies and groups. Numerous methamphetamine cases have been successfully investigated and prosecuted by federal agencies, in close coordination with the state and local law enforcement agencies.
column5: The information provided in this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the deliberative process. This statement does not appear to involve any such communications, but rather provides a summary of law enforcement efforts and successes related to methamphetamine. As such, it would likely be subject to disclosure under FOIA. There is no need to cite case law to support this conclusion, as it is a straightforward application of the exemption 5 criteria.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Prevention and Education:   The Department of Education is conducting meetings to assess the need for a prevention and education strategy on methamphetamine and will send guidance to local schools to reduce methamphetamine use. A $10 million fund has been authorized from the Forfeiture Fund for methamphetamine reduction activities, and requests are currently being reviewed.
column5: The information provided in the statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The Department of Education's meetings and guidance on methamphetamine prevention and education could be considered part of the agency's decision-making process, and therefore protected from disclosure. Additionally, the review of requests for the $10 million fund could also be considered part of the agency's deliberative process and protected from disclosure.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy (1981), in which the Court held that exemption 5 protects "predecisional communications which are part of the deliberative process leading to a decision."; ; Therefore, it is likely that the information provided in the statement would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Treatment:  As of today, there is no specific treatment protocol for methamphetamine; however, the Administration is funding the study of users' behavior patterns to formulate appropriate protocols.
column5: The statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement appears to be a communication between agency officials discussing ongoing research and decision-making processes related to treatment protocols for methamphetamine. This type of internal deliberation is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" and ensure that officials can engage in frank and candid discussions without fear of public disclosure.; ; In this case, the statement about treatment protocols for methamphetamine appears to be part of an ongoing decision-making process within the Administration, and would likely be considered privileged under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Data Collection:    The National Institute of Justice's Drug Use Forecasting Report is due to be released in May 1997, which will include substantial data on methamphetamine abuse.    The National Institutes of Health is also conducting an in-depth study of the methamphetamine user and will present its preliminary findings at a national conference.
column5: The information regarding the National Institute of Justice's Drug Use Forecasting Report and the National Institutes of Health's study of methamphetamine users would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are normally privileged in the civil discovery process, such as attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and deliberative process materials.; ; In this case, the information regarding the drug use forecasting report and the study of methamphetamine users may contain deliberative process materials, which are documents that reflect the opinions, recommendations, or thought processes of government officials involved in the decision-making process. These materials are typically protected under exemption 5 because they are considered part of the agency's decision-making process and are therefore privileged.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 protects documents that are part of the agency's decision-making process, even if they are not directly related to a specific decision.; ; Therefore, the information regarding the drug use forecasting report and the study of methamphetamine users would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, as it may contain deliberative process materials that are part of the agencies' decision-making processes.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Conferences:    More than 400 people from all over the country and many diverse disciplines have participated (or will participate) in methamphetamine conferences to share information, increase understanding, and propose recommendations to improve the nation's response to the methamphetamine problem.
column5: It is possible that the information about the methamphetamine conferences could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, this would depend on the specific nature of the information being requested and the context in which it was created.; ; For example, if the information pertains to internal discussions or deliberations among government officials about policy decisions related to methamphetamine, it could be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure. On the other hand, if the information is simply a summary of the conferences themselves, including the number of participants and their affiliations, it may not be considered privileged and could be subject to disclosure.; ; There is no specific case law that directly addresses this issue, as it would depend on the specific facts and circumstances of each case. However, courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and have required agencies to demonstrate a specific privilege or protection that applies to the information in question. Therefore, if the agency were to assert exemption 5 to withhold information about the methamphetamine conferences, it would need to provide a clear and specific justification for why the information is privileged and exempt from disclosure.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Publications:       The Office of National Drug Control Policy published two documents in January 1997 on methamphetamine Pulse Check:  Methamphetamine Trends in Five Western States and Hawaii and Recent DAWN Data on Methamphetamine and Speed. The next edition will be released later this month.
column5: It is possible that the publications by the Office of National Drug Control Policy would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are part of the deliberative process, such as pre-decisional documents, inter-agency or intra-agency memoranda, and other records that reflect the give-and-take of the decision-making process. ; ; In this case, the publications may contain information that was part of the agency's deliberative process, such as internal discussions about how to address the methamphetamine problem in the Western states and Hawaii, or how to interpret and present data from the DAWN system. However, it would depend on the specific content of the documents and whether they were created for the purpose of informing agency decision-making or were simply informational in nature.; ; One case that may be relevant is Public Citizen v. Office of Management and Budget, 598 F.3d 865 (D.C. Cir. 2010), in which the court held that a document created by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) that provided guidance to agencies on how to implement a new policy was protected under exemption 5 because it was part of the deliberative process and contained pre-decisional advice. The court noted that the document was not a final agency action and was not intended to be the agency's official position on the policy, but rather was a tool for agencies to use in developing their own policies.; ; Similarly, the methamphetamine publications by the Office of National Drug Control Policy may be considered pre-decisional or advisory in nature, rather than final agency actions, and may contain internal deliberations or recommendations that are protected under exemption 5. However, without more information about the specific content of the documents, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; REPORT ON METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE AND TRAFFICKING IN THE UNITED STATES:   An Update of the National Methamphetamine Strategy
column5: The REPORT ON METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE AND TRAFFICKING IN THE UNITED STATES: An Update of the National Methamphetamine Strategy would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5. This exemption covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(5)).; ; The report is likely an intra-agency memorandum or letter, as it is a document produced by one agency (the National Methamphetamine Strategy) for the use of another agency (potentially the Department of Justice or other law enforcement agencies). The report likely contains sensitive information about ongoing investigations, law enforcement techniques, and other information that could harm law enforcement efforts if disclosed to the public.; ; Case law supports the application of exemption 5 to similar types of law enforcement reports. For example, in Schiller v. NLRB, 964 F.2d 1205 (D.C. Cir. 1992), the court held that a report prepared by the National Labor Relations Board's Division of Advice was protected under exemption 5 because it contained "confidential legal advice and recommendations" that were "predecisional and deliberative." Similarly, in Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 432 F.3d 366 (D.C. Cir. 2005), the court held that a report prepared by the Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility was protected under exemption 5 because it contained "predecisional and deliberative" information about an ongoing investigation.; ; Therefore, the REPORT ON METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE AND TRAFFICKING IN THE UNITED STATES: An Update of the National Methamphetamine Strategy would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: No, this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Additionally, this statement does not contain any information that would be considered privileged or confidential. It is a statement of fact about drug trafficking and does not reveal any sensitive information that would harm national security or other interests if disclosed.; ; There is no case law specifically addressing whether a statement like this would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, as it is not a communication between agencies or within an agency. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: No, the statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ;         B. The Administration's Response.
column5: It is possible that the Administration's Response could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. This exemption includes materials that are subject to attorney-client privilege, attorney work product, and deliberative process privilege.; ; If the Administration's Response contains legal advice or analysis provided by an attorney, it could be protected under attorney-client privilege. Similarly, if the Response contains materials created in anticipation of litigation, such as legal strategy or arguments, it could be protected under attorney work product.; ; Additionally, if the Response contains materials that reflect the agency's internal deliberations or decision-making process, it could be protected under deliberative process privilege. This privilege covers materials that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and reflect the agency's internal discussions and considerations.; ; However, whether the Administration's Response is actually protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific contents of the Response and the circumstances surrounding its creation. For example, if the Response contains purely factual information or was created after a final decision was made, it may not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports the application of exemption 5 includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the deliberative process privilege, and United States v. Mead Corp. (2001), which clarified the scope of attorney-client privilege under FOIA.

column5: The information described in the scenario may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The development of a plan to address the methamphetamine problem could involve discussions and deliberations among government officials that are intended to be confidential in order to facilitate candid and effective decision-making. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect "the decision-making processes of government agencies" by ensuring that officials can communicate freely and openly without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials that are "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and that reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The court explained that such materials are protected because they "reflect the agency's group thinking and therefore are part of the decision-making process." ; ; In sum, the information described in the scenario may be protected under exemption 5 if it consists of predecisional and deliberative materials that reflect the agency's decision-making process.

column5: It is possible that Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) initiatives could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, this would depend on the specific nature of the initiatives and the types of communications involved.; ; For example, if the initiatives involved internal discussions or deliberations among DEA officials about potential enforcement strategies or tactics, these communications could potentially be protected under exemption 5 as pre-decisional and deliberative. Similarly, if the initiatives involved communications between the DEA and other law enforcement agencies or government entities, these communications could potentially be protected under exemption 5 as inter-agency or intra-agency memoranda or letters.; ; However, if the initiatives involved final agency actions or decisions, such as the implementation of a new enforcement policy or the issuance of a public statement, these actions or decisions would generally not be protected under exemption 5. Additionally, if the initiatives involved communications with non-governmental entities or individuals, such as private companies or advocacy groups, these communications would generally not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports the potential application of exemption 5 to DEA initiatives includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established the pre-decisional and deliberative privilege, and EPA v. Mink (1973), which established the inter-agency or intra-agency privilege. However, the specific application of these privileges would depend on the facts and circumstances of each case.

For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protected internal agency memoranda that were part of the agency's deliberative process and contained recommendations and opinions about how to handle a particular case. ; ; Overall, while it is possible that the above statement could be protected under exemption 5, the specific facts and context of the situation would need to be carefully considered to determine whether or not it actually qualifies for protection.

column5: It is possible that information related to successful prosecutions could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies, including attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and deliberative process privilege. ; ; For example, if the information pertains to legal advice given by an agency's attorney in the course of a successful prosecution, it could be considered attorney-client communication and therefore exempt from disclosure. Similarly, if the information pertains to the agency's internal deliberations or decision-making process leading up to a successful prosecution, it could be considered deliberative process privilege and exempt from disclosure.; ; However, it is important to note that exemption 5 is not an absolute exemption and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure. Additionally, in NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978), the Supreme Court held that the government could withhold records related to an ongoing enforcement proceeding under FOIA exemption 7(A) if their release could reasonably be expected to interfere with the government's ability to obtain necessary information or to conduct an effective investigation.

column5: The statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement appears to be a communication between members of the Administration discussing the effectiveness of their efforts to combat methamphetamine trafficking and abuse. This type of internal communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure.; ; In this case, the statement appears to be an internal communication between members of the Administration discussing the effectiveness of their efforts to combat methamphetamine trafficking and abuse. As such, it would likely be considered a privileged communication under exemption 5 and exempt from disclosure under FOIA.
